title: James Oglethorpe Monument
text:
The James Oglethorpe Monument is a public <a href="monument">monument</a> in <a href="Chippewa%20Square%20%28Savannah%2C%20Georgia%29">Chippewa Square</a>, <a href="Savannah%2C%20Georgia">Savannah</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. The monument honors <a href="James%20Oglethorpe">James Oglethorpe</a>, the founder of the <a href="Province%20of%20Georgia">Province of Georgia</a>, who established the city of Savannah in 1733. Efforts towards the monument's erection began in 1901 and were led by members of several patriotic groups in the city, who secured <a href="government%20funding">government funding</a> for the monument. The monument consists of a bronze statue of Oglethorpe, designed by <a href="Daniel%20Chester%20French">Daniel Chester French</a>, atop a large granite pedestal designed by <a href="Henry%20Bacon">Henry Bacon</a>. It was dedicated in 1910, in a ceremony that attracted several thousand spectators and was attended by several notable government officials.
History.
Background.
<a href="James%20Oglethorpe">James Oglethorpe</a> was a soldier and philanthropist who founded the <a href="Province%20of%20Georgia">Province of Georgia</a> in 1732, after a charter was granted by the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Great%20Britain">Parliament of Great Britain</a> to the <a href="Georgia%20Trustees">Georgia Trustees</a>. In November of that year, Oglethorpe and a group of over a hundred people set sail from <a href="England">England</a> to colonize the new province, and on February 12, 1733, these settlers established the city of <a href="Savannah%2C%20Georgia">Savannah, Georgia</a>, at <a href="Yamacraw%20Bluff">Yamacraw Bluff</a> on the <a href="Savannah%20River">Savannah River</a>. Oglethorpe was directly involved in the colony's growth over the next several years, and he led the colony's defenses during the <a href="War%20of%20Jenkins%27%20Ear">War of Jenkins' Ear</a> against the <a href="Spanish%20Empire">Spanish Empire</a>, which began in 1739. In 1742, forces under Oglethorpe's command successfully repelled the Spanish <a href="Invasion%20of%20Georgia%20%281742%29">invasion of Georgia</a>, and the following year, Oglethorpe led an unsuccessful attack on the Spanish settlement of <a href="St.%20Augustine%2C%20Florida">St. Augustine</a>. Following this, Oglethorpe was called to return to England, where he eventually died in 1785.
Erection.
On May 18, 1901, the Oglethorpe Monument Association was granted a charter by the <a href="Superior%20Court">Superior Court</a> of <a href="Chatham%20County%2C%20Georgia">Chatham County</a>. The association was founded with the goal of raising funds and coordinating efforts between several patriotic groups for the erection of a <a href="monument">monument</a> honoring Oglethorpe in Savannah. The association was made up of six representatives each from four patriotic groups: The <a href="National%20Society%20of%20the%20Colonial%20Dames%20of%20America">Georgia Society of Colonial Dames of America</a>, the <a href="Sons%20of%20the%20Revolution">Sons of the Revolution</a>, the <a href="Daughters%20of%20the%20American%20Revolution">Daughters of the American Revolution</a>, and the <a href="Society%20of%20Colonial%20Wars">Society of Colonial Wars</a>. The association held its first meeting on November 28, 1902, and by 1905, it had raised approximately $5,000.
That summer, the president of the Colonial Dames urged state representatives from Chatham County to secure aid for the monument from the <a href="Georgia%20General%20Assembly">Georgia General Assembly</a>, and on July 12, they introduced a <a href="joint%20resolution">joint resolution</a> to the <a href="Georgia%20House%20of%20Representatives">Georgia House of Representatives</a> to provide for the erection of the monument. On August 10, the resolution passed through the <a href="Appropriation%20bill">appropriations</a> committee recommending $15,000 to be allocated for the monument's erection. The resolution was voted down and reconsidered several times into the next year in the General Assembly. Finally, on August 13, an amended version of the bill was approved by the House of Representatives, and was approved by the <a href="Georgia%20State%20Senate">Georgia State Senate</a> two days later. The resolution was then signed into law by <a href="Georgia%20Governor">Georgia Governor</a> <a href="Joseph%20M.%20Terrell">Joseph M. Terrell</a>. An amendment added to the resolution on August 2, 1906, stipulated that the monument would be erected in <a href="Chippewa%20Square%20%28Savannah%2C%20Georgia%29">Chippewa Square</a>, which was <a href="state%20property">state property</a>. The <a href="Government%20of%20Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">state government</a> appropriated the $15,000 allocation in half increments between 1907 and 1908. 
Following the resolution's passage, the governor assembled a commission of seven people to oversee the project. In fall 1906, the commission selected sculptor <a href="Daniel%20Chester%20French">Daniel Chester French</a>, who at the time was associated with the <a href="architect">architect</a> <a href="Henry%20Bacon">Henry Bacon</a>, to design the monument. French designed the <a href="statue">statue</a> of Oglethorpe, while Bacon was responsible for the design of the <a href="pedestal">pedestal</a>. Several years later, the two would collaborate to design the <a href="Lincoln%20Memorial">Lincoln Memorial</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> In designing the statue, French decided to portray Oglethorpe as a military commander, and he drew on many portraits of Oglethorpe to ensure an accurate portrayal. On May 10, 1909, several commission members appeared before the city government of Savannah and petitioned for $15,000 in additional funding for the monument, having realized shortly before that the cost for the monument could not be covered by then-available funds. The government approved the request and additional funds were raised by the patriotic groups. The total cost of the monument was $38,000. In 1910, two <a href="Bust%20%28sculpture%29">busts</a> of <a href="Confederate%20States%20Army">Confederate States Army</a> generals <a href="Francis%20S.%20Bartow">Francis S. Bartow</a> and <a href="Lafayette%20McLaws">Lafayette McLaws</a> were removed from Chippewa Square to make way for the Oglethorpe monument. These busts were relocated to near the <a href="Confederate%20Monument%20%28Savannah%2C%20Georgia%29">Confederate Monument</a> (now the Civil War Memorial) in <a href="Forsyth%20Park">Forsyth Park</a>.
Dedication.
The monument was unveiled on November 23, 1910. Prior to its unveiling, it was covered by the flags of <a href="Flag%20of%20Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a> and <a href="Flag%20of%20England">England</a>. The ceremony was a large event attended by many notable individuals, including Georgia Governor <a href="Joseph%20M.%20Brown">Joseph M. Brown</a>, <a href="Alabama%20Governor">Alabama Governor</a> <a href="B.%20B.%20Comer">B. B. Comer</a>, <a href="Senators%20from%20Georgia">Senators</a> <a href="Augustus%20O.%20Bacon">Augustus O. Bacon</a> and <a href="Joseph%20M.%20Terrell">Joseph M. Terrell</a>, <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20Representatives%20from%20Georgia">Representative</a> <a href="Charles%20G.%20Edwards">Charles G. Edwards</a>, and Chancellor <a href="David%20C.%20Barrow">David C. Barrow</a> of the <a href="University%20of%20Georgia">University of Georgia</a>, among others. Multiple <a href="Company%20%28military%20unit%29">military companies</a> and thousands of spectators were also in attendance. The <a href="invocation">invocation</a> for the monument was given by Bishop <a href="Frederick%20F.%20Reese">Frederick F. Reese</a> of the <a href="Episcopal%20Diocese%20of%20Georgia">Episcopal Diocese of Georgia</a>. Following this, multiple addresses were made, including one by <a href="A.%20Mitchell%20Innes">A. Mitchell Innes</a>, then-acting <a href="British%20ambassador">British ambassador</a>. Following these addresses, French and the <a href="chairman">chairman</a> of the commission led Brown and J. J. Wilder, the president of the Society of Colonial Dames of America, to the monument, where the two of them removed the flags and officially unveiled the monument.
On the next day, <a href="Thanksgiving%20%28United%20States%29">Thanksgiving</a>, the <a href="Georgia%20Bulldogs%20football">Georgia Bulldogs</a> and the <a href="Auburn%20Tigers%20football">Auburn Tigers</a> played <a href="Deep%20South%27s%20Oldest%20Rivalry">their annual football rivalry game</a> in a field near Chippewa Square as part of further celebrations for the monument. The governors of Georgia and Alabama (where <a href="Auburn%20University">Auburn University</a> is located) were among the 5,000 people in attendance.In 1957, the <a href="Georgia%20Historical%20Commission">Georgia Historical Commission</a> erected a <a href="Georgia%20historical%20marker">Georgia historical marker</a> near the monument, describing its history.
Design.
The statue of Oglethorpe is made of <a href="bronze">bronze</a> and stands tall. Oglethorpe is depicted as wearing a contemporary military uniform from the 1700s, including a <a href="cuirass">cuirass</a>, <a href="waistcoat">waistcoat</a>, boots, and a <a href="tricorn%20hat">tricorn hat</a>. Additionally, he is wearing a <a href="wig">wig</a> similar to one he is depicted as having worn. Oglethorpe holds a sword in his hand, and a <a href="Sabal">palmetto</a> <a href="frond">frond</a> is next to his feet. The statue faces towards the south, which, according to the Georgia Historical Society, symbolizes "the threat of Spain’s imperial ambitions to the young colony."
The <a href="pedestal">pedestal</a> for the statue is made of pink-gray <a href="marble">marble</a> and was designed in the <a href="Italian%20Renaissance%20architecture">Italian Renaissance</a> style. The pedestal itself rests on a large square base that has four <a href="lion%20rampant">lion rampant</a>s, one on each corner. Each lion is holding a shield that depicts Oglethorpe's personal <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a> and the seals of <a href="Seal%20of%20Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">the state of Georgia</a>, the colony of Georgia, and the city of Savannah. The base is further decorated with <a href="garland">garland</a>s.
